top_comment.text:
My kitten won't leave our older cat alone , he takes his food, jumps on him 
when he s sat quiet , chases his tail, the older cat is sick of it, what 
can I do ? ﻿
top_comment.author: chris preston

comments.text: My cats just got used to each other. Let them do their thing.
comments.author: Feline Fanatic

comments.text:
Kittens are so full of energy, it's amazing. Maybe try playing with him and 
wearing him out a bit, he seems to lack stimulation from you so he's trying 
to find it with another cat, which in the end, doesn't even want to play 
with him.
comments.author: CA Tol

comments.text:
My 5 yr old does it to my 10yr old cat.too. I cant quiet her down. Have you 
tried hebal remedies? I did at one stage and it seemed to work. Will try 
them again soon.
comments.author: Lynne Elliott

top_comment.text:
My female cat has, what I call, "bad" habbit to lick om soft plastic, like 
plastic bags for example. Why does she do that? The noise of her licking 
it, is extremley annoying to me.. How does I made her stop? (removing 
the plastic bags helps ofc, but there is a bit of soft plastic stuck 
on under the couch)﻿
top_comment.author: Julia Shepherd

comments.text:
Just ignore it 
If u don't ignore it she will keep doing it,but if u ignore it she won't 
know why she is doing it so she will stop.*learned that from Jackson btw
comments.author: Debanti Styless

comments.text:
You need to take your cat to the vet. Cats that eat non-food items (though 
I don't think your cat is EATING the plastic) have something called pika. 
She might not be getting enough of a particular nutrient; your vet can have 
some bloodwork done and check for that. And yes, keep as much plastic away 
from her as possible. The last thing you want to have happen is your cat 
suffocating on plastic.
comments.author: TVC15ohoh

comments.text:
My male cat does that, too, as well as tape and reusable shopping bags.  He 
has a very sensitive stomach and I notice he only licks plastic when his 
stomach bothers him.  I switched him to a grain-free, limited ingredient, 
mostly wet food diet and that really seems to help, he doesn't do it as 
nearly as much as he used to.  In fact sometimes I can even leave plastic 
bags out and he doesn't touch them.
comments.author: Lakshmi Mudgal

top_comment.text:
So my felines are puking, and one is very skinny and the other over weight, 
we have tried doing many things, from feeding less, seprate eatings, we 
can't seem to get the one from gaining and the other to lose, we tried 
diffrent food for a time even, any other suggestions?﻿
top_comment.author: Cyan Hunt

comments.text:
my cat used to puke but i get him easy digestible cat
food and problem solved..:) maybe you could try..:)
comments.author: 8auspiciousdragons

comments.text:
I have 1 cat that is overweight and two that tend to being skinny.

For the overweight one  I tried the vet only obesity foods (eg Science Diet 
& Royal Canin) and she didn't loose any weight, just maintained for a 
couple of years. Tried a new vet and she recommended just feeding her no 
grain wet food (like fish or mince)  I opted for feeding her mince so I 
could use it to lead her through simple exercises as she is VERY food 
motivated  (walking up and down a few stairs inbetween each piece or 
jumping up and down from a chair) She has now lost about 1 1/4 kgs in 4 
months (which is  alot for a cat). Vet also thought my cats obsession with 
food might have come from her being a stray (she was only 4kg's when I got 
her and had put on 2kgs within a couple of months). I have been a bit slack 
in the last couple of months and some biscuits have crept in again but she 
is continuing to gradually loose weight so I'm hoping my early efforts have 
kick started her metabolism again.

For my underweight cat the vet recommended feeding them biscuits biscuits 
and more biscuits as they are full of carbs which helps put on weight. It 
has worked to a point but they are both pretty active cats and burn it off 
pretty easily (one is 4 and the other nearly 12 and the 12 year old is the 
more playful and energetic!)

Hope this is helpful.
comments.author: Jenny Floyd

top_comment.text:
I have a very insecure siamese that gets bulled by my bengal, i get so 
frustated!!﻿
top_comment.author: Stacey Crossley

comments.text:
Zoe's completely right - sometimes I find that I pretty much have to 
exhaust my bengal with play so that he'll leave  my other kitties alone. He 
definitely takes more time and effort to take care of properly.
comments.author: troxycat

comments.text:
Hi Stacey.  Bengal cats are a perfect example of the "raw" cat times 10.  
They are a Hybrid cat and require a lot of hard work.  They are very 
territorial and will make every available effort to "claim"  the space.  
They require lots of exercise and are definitely tree dwellers.  Make sure 
you have lots of high spaces for them all over your home and it's a very 
good idea to have 2-3 cat boxes even if your cats can go outside.  Playing 
with them is also very good.  Understanding the Bengal is key to keeping 
the peace in the house.  Good luck with this.
comments.author: Zoe Skyflyer

top_comment.text:
Do you have any ideas for low impact play for older cats? One ofm y cats is 
turning 16 soon and my other cat is starting to get older as well. ﻿
top_comment.author: drfetusface

comments.text:
My dear bubbles still played up until she was 21, an old tie does the 
trick:)
comments.author: char_

comments.text:
The Almighty Laser works wonders for my 18 year old.  He can run and chase 
it and I don't need to make him jump around for exercise, just run him out 
a bit.
comments.author: donica deeski

top_comment.text:
I just got a new cat in november, and she has given me loads of problems.

We already have a male cat (6 years old). He's calm, and cuddly.
And she (6 months old now) Is all over the house, playfull and cuddly.

But.. She pees in the house. Not in the litter box.
I tried everything.

I bought an extra litter box, I tried training her...

She still pees on the couch, the corners of the house and in the beds.

I don't know what to do. But this seems to happen everytime she has, to say 
it as it is, taken a dump.

She burries her poo in the litter, then, she goes to the closest corner 
(away from any of the litter boxes) and pees.
I am frustrated. I empty the litterbox 5 times a day, and everytime I hear 
her go into the box to poo, I run up to empty it imidiatly. but it's still 
like she refuses to pee in the box right after she pooed in it. Please. 
Help. I dont know what I am doing wrong﻿
top_comment.author: Caroline “VampireCherry” Andersen

comments.text:
You are going about it all wrong your cat is nervous! Cats do that they are 
unsure of their place in the house. Also emptying the box that much just 
adds to the problem check out this guy's video on litter.
comments.author: Ainsleigh Walker

comments.text:
Try to put a litterbox on or near the place she pees for maybe it's a 
territorial issue.
comments.author: DiekeDrake

comments.text:
I think there are several possibilities. 1 she is becoming adult and this 
will stop when she will be sterilized (i know this is the case with male 
cats, not sure about the females), some cats just dont like to pee in the 
dirty litter box, some cats are very picky about how clean their bathrooms 
are. I got rid of my problem (i have like 4+cats and one male cat had the 
same problem) when i bought 2 extra huge plastic boxes (i think its 
75cm*50cm). it is said that for a cat you would need +1 litter box. aka if 
u have 2 cats, then 3 litter boxes. but in my case the 2 huge ones worked 
very well. also it can be the litter material itself. the extra clumping 
works best for my case.

Also if it wont fix your problem, then i think you should get your cat 
checked @ the doc, cuz she might have some bladder issues. but i dont think 
this is the case right now. Well good luck and dont punish your cat, 
because she doesnt misbehave on purpose :)
comments.author: batmannu

top_comment.text: I had no idea you were vegan. Now I just want to marry you even more =P﻿

I need to reach Jackson Galaxy as I have a 6 month old who bites.  
Everything I have tried, along with watching all Jackson's videos and 
applying his principles are not working.  Thank you.  Debbie and Lucy﻿
top_comment.author: Deb Smith

comments.text:
I got her through my local animal shelter.  She had been brought in as a 
stray with her brother who had the same biting issues.  When I realized her 
tendency to bite, I never played with her with my hands.  I am home with 
her all day long and the only toy I play with are the wands and am doing 
clicker training now.  She was only 3 months when I adopted her and had 
been living under someone deck since the age of 2 months, so she has never 
been socialized by an adult cat and thinks I am a walking toy.  Her biting 
is getting progressively worse.  BTW, what is a kicker toy you mentioned?  
Thank you :-)
comments.author: Deb Smith

comments.text:
By chance has anyone played with kitty with hands .. Allot of times biting 
starts with rough play with hands .. Should get his attention on to another 
toy like a kicker those things are great toys.. Gets a lot of aggression 
out of them...

comments.text:
I think it depends a bit on the cat too. I'm a petsitter so I try this on 
new furry clients to reassure them, especially the "shy" ones. Most respond 
but not all.

While my own cats do respond to the blink they also respond to me smiling 
at them or telling them how cute they are so I think a lot of it is about 
the vibe you're giving out when you do it.
comments.author: Jenny Floyd

comments.text:
Give it time up until now you haven't been speaking her language so she 
doesn't quite know what to think (my cats did the same thing) Once they put 
it together you will see their affection for you spring board.
GBY
comments.author: Pastor Shawn

top_comment.text:
hey Jackson, I have a blind cat, became blind 4+ years ago....he gets 
around really well in my home but I may have to move in the next year.  How 
can I help him to acclimate and be comfortable and happy in a new home?  It 
will be very different than what he is used to and I am very hesitant to 
move him as he is so used to our home.  and he is my fluffy man.﻿
top_comment.author: Sue T.

comments.text:
+Barb Grajewski Thanks for your reply.  yeah he does not know he is unable 
to do certain things he used to be able to do and I think his vision has 
always been compromised even as a kitten (found feral) he seemed to have 
vision issues.  All your suggestions are very good and I will keep them in 
mind.
comments.author: Sue T.

comments.text:
This is a great question, and I hope others can chime in.  My best guess 
would be that maybe training to verbal and smell/food queues, so that he 
can find what he needs in the new location would be helpful?  Like, every 
time he's in the litter pan, say, "Litter! Good boy!".  When in the new 
place, put him in/near the litter, or when he finds it, repeat, "Litter! 
Good boy!"  Start him in the new place in one small room, laid out nearly 
to what you've got now and gradually expand his territory?  Dealing with 
"differently abled" cats is a challenge, but THEY don't seem to know 
they're "disabled" as much as we do!  Maybe Jackson can present some info 
on cats with special needs now and then.
comments.author: Barb Grajewski

top_comment.text:
Here's one for ya-- my cat likes to mop the floor.  On a perfectly clean 
floor, she will dip her paw in the water dish and start to paw the floor 
like she would as if she was trying to paw away litter when she steps out 
of the box.  She will do this in the kitchen, bathroom, anywhere there's a 
hard floor.  She's even done it after a fresh mop job.  It's gotten to the 
point where she would do it and the result would be an overturned water 
dish, resulting in another human mop.  Her water dish now resides in the 
bathtub.  Any tips for this one?  ~Shivani and Raj﻿
top_comment.author: Merciless Bow

comments.text:
+Funlaughinlady she out only cat and her water is replaced when it runs out 
or just really needs refilling well try the fresh water tip thank you
comments.author: Merciless Bow

comments.text:
@ Raj asbury I'm just curious is the water cold? Or is the bowl shared with 
other cats. I had that same issue with my Mr. Of the house and found that 
room temp water/ and new water twice daily. Was good. But inviting him to 
watch me poor the water from a pitcher into his bowl and saying a command 
"fresh water" in just two fresh bowls never again. Other suggestion. Get a 
small water fountain for his play time when your in shower. And see if he 
just wants to play in water.
comments.author: Funlaughinlady

captions.text: What is this?
This Is Cat Mojo 101.

The ultimate, the archetypal,
the omniscient and omnipotent,

the all consuming, all
knowing, Cat Mojo 101,

let's get prehistorically
moj-ified, cat-ified, let's
go-ify right now.
Unh!

So a funny thing
happened to me on the way
to making this here video.

The thing is, I thought
I made this here video.

I thought I made this
here video 1,000 times

over in my head,
which was the problem.

Because I made this video 1,000
times over my head, and never
actually made it to this.
What is Cat Mojo?

It Is what propels a cat
forward through this lifetime

with confidence, with
security, with the knowledge

that I am doing what I was
put on this planet to do.

Now fortunately, cats got
it made a lot better than we

do, because we spend our
entire lives, you know,

going to like Liberal Arts
college, trying to figure out,

like what is it I'm
on this planet to do?

Cats know from the
moment they're born.

So the way we're
going to break it down

is, this here fork that
I'm holding in my hand.

The first prong of the
Fork of Mojo is what?
The Confident Who.

The second prong of the
Fork of Mojo-- bing,

that would be the
Confident What.

And finally, the
Confident Where.
Who is the Confident Who?
Confident Who is the Raw Cat.

The Raw Cat is that cat way in
the back of your cat's head,

thousands and thousands
and thousands of years ago.

That African desert cat that
is the hunter, the catcher,

the killer, the eater,
the groomer, the sleeper.
Bang!
That is the Raw Cat.

The process of quote,
"domesticating" cats

has been nothing like
domesticating dogs.

Dogs, we basically take
them out of the wild.

We say you know
what, I like you.

I like what you do, I want
you to do a job for me,
act like this.

And when we started
storing grains and whatnot,

we said wait a minute, the
cat's killing the mice,

and the things that
are ruining our food.
Let's keep them around.

So we didn't do
anything to them.

The second prong on my Fork
of Mojo is the Confident What.
This is all about body language.

We talked about this before,
the Mojito cat, now we've

talked about the other
types of Unconfident Whos.
What do they do?

That would be the Wall Flower,
and then we have the Napoleon,
aka the over-owner.

Go back and look
at those videos,

you'll know about the
Mojito cat, the Wall Flower

Cat, and the Napoleon
cat, and those three

are examples of
the Confident What.

The third prong on
the Fork of Mojo

that you see right
here-- bing, that would
be the Confident Where.

Bush dwellers, tree dwellers,
beach dwellers, right?

Where do they accentuate
their mojo-osity right now.
What about the Confident How.
That's your job.

Your homework is to
find the Confident How.
Play is pray.
Pray is Mojo.

Playing with your cat is not
like taking a little time out.

It's about as important
as walking your dog.

It gets the Confident
Who out in your house.

Play is the most
important thing that you

can do with your cat
on a daily basis.

So many of the problems that
you guys are writing in to me

about, Jackson why
does my cat do this,

don't worry about why they're
doing it half the time.
First, start by playing.

How can you also bring
out Mojo in your cat?

You're going to think I'm
crazy, but this is true.
It's about food, people.
Bio appropriate diet.

When you're talking
about an animal that

is so close to wild
you can taste it,

that's the thing, they're
not out there hunting,
but what do they need?

Their body informs
their Mojo just as much

as their mind
informs their Mojo.

So don't forget, your cats
are obligate carnivores,

and they need to eat meat, and
they need to eat it every day.
I am vegan, I do not eat animal.
My cats have to.

You can cater to
the Confident Who

with every moment of every day,
whether it is scheduling them

through play and diet, whether
it is building up in the world,

or building down in the world,
where their Mojo comes to bear,

I'm telling you folks,
the why about your cat

doing what they do in
your house falls away
when you cater to the Mojo.

How can I help my cat
demonstrate their Cat Mojo?

Tell me about it, write to
me here, right down here

at the bottom, leave a
comment, subscribe to this,

so you can find out
what's going on next.

Also you can find me on my
website jacksongalaxy.com,

you can find me, I am on
the Animalist network,

clearly, because this is
the Animalist network,

also you can find me on
Facebook, and on Twitter,
and on Instagram.

I am wherever you are, and
I'd love to hear from you.

If you haven't noticed, take a
look at this, will you please,
right behind me.

This is my man Benny,
he was presented to me,

we were doing a case for "My
Cat from Hell" in San Diego,

and at the end of the case,
these wonderful people,

their friend, her name
is Kathryn Johncox,

and Catherine presented me with
this gorgeous piece of artwork.
And I wish her all the best.

Catherine, you rock
my world, I've never

seen anything capture
Benny as much as you did,
and I mean that's him.

That's that boy who launched the
book, who launched the career,

and now he looms
over me, telling me
what I'm doing wrong.
Thank you so much, Catherine.

And I thank you for joining
me, for doing your homework,

for loving your cat,
until the next time

we meet folks, all light,
all love, all Mojo to you.
You're a bad cat,
I'm not a bad cat,
You're a bad cat,
I'm just misunderstood.
Meow.
